 & 9 \\

\end{array}\\]
So $629_{10}=900_7+\cdots$, now continue repeating process...

Remaining quotient : Quotient without last figure - Last figure/factorial\\

subanswer.text:
Let's break it down into steps. To convert decimal numbers like 629 to another system such as Base Seven (Base 7):  
Step one - Divide your original number by seven repeatedly until you get zero quotient. Write each time divided value separately starting from bottom upward till now i.e., keep dividing leftmost digit first; write new right most division outcomes below previous ones accordingly. That’s how easy converting large decimals becomes! Here goes :

num = int('629')

ost_step.1: Now let us do similar operation but instead multiply rather than adding individual components obtained during above process… Multiply them together alongwith respective exponents based upon place holder position while calculating powers respectively too . direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, first convert the decimal number $629_{10}$ into both base 7 and base 8 forms. Converting to base 7 involves dividing repeatedly by 7 until you reach zero as shown below:
\begin{align*}
629 &÷ 7 = 89 R 6 \\
89 &÷ 7 = 12 R 5 \\
12 &÷ 7 = 1 R 5 \\
1 &÷ 7 = 0 R 1 \\
\end{align*}
Thus, $629_{10} = 1556_7$. Similarly, converting it to base 8 yields:
\begin{align*}
629 &÷ 8 = 78 R 3 \\
78 &÷ 8 = 9 R 6 \\
9 &÷ 8 = 1 R 1 \\
1 &÷ 8 = 0 R 1 \\
\end{align*}
So, $629_{10} = 1113_8$. Comparing bases side by side reveals no shared digits since every digit appears unique

Understanding the original query involves identifying how one can determine the presence of identical digits when representing a particular value in both base seven (base 7) and base eight (base 8). Given the principles outlined:

Conditions apply strictly to whole numbers represented either in base sixteen (hexadecimal notation typically denoted as "_16"), hexadecimal (denoted as "_Hex" - usually meaning Base 16), septemvigesimal (Base 27 referring to seventeen times eleven plus one), sexagesimal (Base 60 referring to sixty hours), decaoctal (Base 10 referred to 'Oct', symbolising Octave music scales related notes arrangement starting from Middle C followed by D

0.user_question: How many of the same digits are found in the base 7 and base 8 representations of $629_{10}$? For example, $121_{3}$ and $413_{5}$ would have one digit in common.

1.subquestion: Convert $629_{10}$ to its equivalent representation in base 7.

subanswer.text:
First let us convert it into binary since most people know how to do so easily..We start off dividing our decimal value into powers of four as below..$$\begin{array}{c|cc}
& \text {Quotient } & \\
\hline
629 \div 4 &  157&\\
157 \div 4=39&\underline{-32}&3\\
39 \div 4=9&\underline{-32}&9\\
9 \div 4=2&\underline{-8}&11\\
2 \div 4=&0&\blacksquare\\
\end{array}$$So now writing each quotient column backwards... $$\begin{aligned}
629 &= 1\cdot 4^{3}+9\cdot 4^{2}+11\cdot 4^{1}+3 \\
&=1413_7
\end{aligned}$$ Now what about converting back using power of seven again ? $$1413_7 = 1\cdot 7^{3}+4\cdot 7^{2}+1\cdot 7^{1}+3\cdot 7^{0}=1*

```

7 | 629

Correct value becomes actually > carryover happens when subtraction doesn't yield proper results.. --> Revised steps following correct procedure...

subanswer.text: To convert $629_{10}$ to base 7, divide repeatedly by 7 until getting zeroes as quotients:\[\begin{array}{c|c@{}l}

direct_answer.text: Let's begin by converting $629_{10}$ into base 7 using repeated division by 7.\[\\\]To start off our conversion process,\[ \\]\[(629÷7=97r2)\]After dividing once by 7, we get a remainder of 2, so now let’s continue onto the next round of divisions:\\\[(97÷7=13r6)\]This time around when divided results in another whole number but leaves us a remainder of 6; repeating again yields:\\\[(13÷7=1r6)\\]\[\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c}\textbf{Base }& 10 & 7 &\textbf{Place value}\\ \hline 629_{10} & - & 2 & { }\underline{\hphantom{0}}\\  629_{10} & 9 & 6 & { } 6\\  629_{10} & 97 & \underline{2} & {\underline{13}}\end{array}\][\]\[\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c}\textbf{Remainder}& \
